columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about the pricing equation of options.

To start with, let us define options.

**Options** are types of financial contracts which give the holder the right, but not the obligation to buy or sell a specific asset at a predetermined price, on or before its date of expiration.

Here are the parameters to solve the problem : 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Current Stock Price |$845 | 
|Maximum Possible Stock Price |$81 | 
|Minimum Possible Stock Price |$64 | 
|Exercise Price |$70 | 
|Yield | 3%|

To start with, let us solve the stock price: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Stock Price}&=\frac{\text{Price of the Contact}}{100}\\[2pt]
&=\frac{\$845}{100}\\[20pt]
&=\$8.45
\end{aligned}$$

The price of the one-year call option contract is divided by 100 to determine the current stock price. 

Therefore, the current stock price is $8.45.

Now, let us solve the current value of the stock : 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Current Value}&=\left[\left(\frac{\text{Max-Min}}{\text{Max-EP}}\right)\text{CSP}\right]+\left(\frac{\text{Min}}{\text{1+Yield}}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\left[\left(\frac{\$81-\$64}{\$81-\$70}\right)\$8.45\right]+\left(\frac{\$64}{1+0.03}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\left(\frac{17}{11}\times\$8.45\right)+\frac{\$64}{1.0.3}\\[20pt]
&=\left(\$1.5455\times\$8.45\right)+\$62.14\\[20pt]
&=\$13.06+\$62.14\\[20pt]
&=\boxed{\$75.20}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the current value of the stock is $75.20.
